items.title: Microsoft reportedly fires staff whose protest interrupted its Copilot event
items.summary:
- On April 7, 2025, Microsoft reportedly terminated two software engineers, Ibtihal Aboussad and Vaniya Agrawal, following their protest during the Copilot event.
- Aboussad interrupted Microsoft AI CEO Mustafa Suleyman, accusing him of having "blood on his hands," while Agrawal shouted at a panel including CEO Satya Nadella and Bill Gates for Microsoft to cut ties with Israel.
- The internal message from Microsoft indicated that the employees should have raised concerns privately rather than disrupting the event.

items.title: Amazon says its AI video model can now generate minutes-long clips
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Amazon upgraded its AI video model, Nova Reel, to generate videos up to two minutes long.
- Nova Reel can create "multi-shot" videos with consistent styles; users can provide prompts up to 4,000 characters.
- A new mode, "Multishot Manual," allows referencing images for better video composition.
- Nova Reel is available through AWS services, and its training data source has not been disclosed, raising IP concerns.

items.title: How one tweet wreaked havoc on the stock market
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- A false tweet from Walter Bloomberg suggested President Trump was considering a 90-day pause on tariffs, causing market volatility.
- The erroneous report led to significant fluctuations in index funds like the Dow Jones before being retracted.
- The White House quickly denied the statements attributed to its economic adviser Kevin Hassett, who has not made such claims.
- Reuters and CNBC later acknowledged their roles in propagating the misinformation, with Reuters retracting its original report.

items.title: Nikola founder Trevor Milton wants to buy the bankrupt startup’s assets
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
• Trevor Milton, founder of Nikola, seeks to purchase his former company's assets from bankruptcy.
• Nikola filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in February, aiming to sell its business by mid-April.
• Milton's bid faced opposition; he was denied access to inspect factory assets.
• He was recently pardoned after serving time for securities fraud.
• An auction for Nikola's assets is scheduled for April 7 to determine the highest offer.

items.title: Flexport CEO Ryan Petersen’s high-stakes test amid tariff turmoil: ‘You can’t be freaking out’
items.summary:
- Ryan Petersen, CEO of Flexport, addressed over 2,300 customers following President Trump’s new tariffs defined as “Liberation Day.”
- The tariffs could reach up to 79% on various products from China, significantly impacting U.S. importers and port operations.
- The closure of the de minimis program for global imports affects many e-commerce businesses now subject to new customs obligations.
- Petersen had already engaged with 200 customers before the tariff announcement, expecting duties on diverse locations including Vietnam.
- Flexport aims to provide stability and guidance to clients amidst tariff chaos, with Petersen emphasizing the need for calm leadership during crises.
- Future disruptions include proposed port fees for ships made in China, predicted to increase costs for U.S. importers.
- Petersen indicated ongoing negotiations with countries like Vietnam and Israel may lead to reciprocal trade agreements shortly.

items.title: Meta exec denies the company artificially boosted Llama 4’s benchmark scores
items.author: Ahmad Al-Dahle
items.summary:
- Meta's VP of generative AI, Ahmad Al-Dahle, denied accusations of artificially boosting Llama 4's benchmark scores.
- Rumors originated from a user on a Chinese social media site, claiming to have resigned from Meta due to its benchmarking practices.
- Reports indicated that Llama 4 models perform poorly on certain tasks, exacerbating skepticism about their capabilities.

items.title: Analyst says Apple, Tesla have biggest exposure to Trump’s tariffs
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives reduced price targets for Apple and Tesla due to President Trump’s tariffs.
- Ives stated that Apple is most negatively affected, with 90% of iPhones produced in China, lowering its target by $75 to $250.
- Tesla's price target cut from $550 to $315, citing not only tariffs but also CEO Elon Musk's political associations impacting sales.

items.title: Former Tesla exec Drew Baglino’s new startup is rethinking the electrical transformer
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Former Tesla executive Drew Baglino has founded Heron Power, focusing on solid-state transformers for the electric grid.
- The startup aims to raise between $30 million to $50 million for its Series A funding round, with Capricorn Investment Group leading.
- Baglino previously worked at Tesla since 2006, and left the company in April 2024 during staff layoffs.
- Solid-state transformers offer improved regulation for voltage dips from renewable sources and feature a more compact design.
- Heron Power is one of several startups targeting the transformer market, competing with Singapore-based Amperesand.

items.title: Waymo may use interior camera data to train generative AI models, sell ads
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Waymo plans to use data from robotaxis, including video from interior cameras tied to rider identities, for training generative AI models.
- The unreleased privacy policy indicates data may also be shared for personalized ads.
- Riders can opt out of sharing their information under California privacy laws, but concern rises over data use for AI training and marketing.
- The company records over 200,000 paid robotaxi rides weekly in cities like Los Angeles and San Francisco.
- Waymo seeks new revenue streams through advertising and data sharing, amid significant financial losses for Alphabet.

items.title: Google’s AI Mode now lets users ask complex questions about images
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google introduces multimodal search in AI Mode, allowing complex, multi-part questions on images.
- Powered by Google Lens, it analyzes entire scenes in photos, understanding relationships and details.
- Users can upload or take photos and ask personalized questions, receiving specific recommendations.
- The feature will be available to a larger audience in Google Labs, previously limited to Google One AI Premium subscribers.
- Launched in March 2025, AI Mode aims to compete with services like ChatGPT Search.

items.title: Shopify CEO tells teams to consider using AI before growing headcount
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Shopify CEO Tobi Lütke implemented a policy requiring teams to justify why AI cannot be used before requesting additional headcount.
- Lütke encourages teams to envision their projects with autonomous AI agents to spark creative solutions.
- This approach aligns with a trend where CEOs like Klarna's Sebastian Siemiatkowski leverage AI to reduce workforce size, with potential job disruptions highlighted by a UN report stating AI could affect over 40% of global roles.
- Shopify had approximately 8,100 employees as of 2024, following significant layoffs in previous years, including a 20% staff reduction in 2023.

items.title: Nintendo says it is ‘actively assessing’ the impact of U.S. tariffs
items.author: Doug Bowser
items.summary:
- Nintendo president Doug Bowser stated the company did not consider potential U.S. tariffs when pricing the Nintendo Switch 2.
- The Switch 2 was announced to be released on June 5, 2025, at a price of $450.
- Due to new tariffs announced by President Trump, U.S. preorders for the Switch 2 set for April 9 will be delayed until Nintendo resolves tariff issues that affect parts manufactured in China, Vietnam, and Cambodia.

items.title: AI video startup Moonvalley raised a fresh $43M, SEC filing shows
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Moonvalley raised $43 million in fresh venture capital according to an SEC filing.
- The startup is developing AI tools for video creation and recently launched its model, Marey.
- Previous funding included $70 million in seed funding from notable backers.
- There is a risk of market oversaturation among AI video generator startups.
- Moonvalley’s Marey offers customization options for video generation and claims lower legal risks.

items.title: UK’s demand for Apple backdoor should not be heard in secret, says court
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- The U.K. government lost its challenge to keep surveillance order details against Apple secret.
- A decision by the Investigatory Powers Tribunal allows public access to parts of the legal case, despite U.K. objections.
- The case involves a demand for Apple to provide access to encrypted cloud data of any customer globally.
- Apple has claimed it cannot provide end-to-end encryption to U.K. users due to this demand.
- Various advocacy groups and lawmakers urge for transparency in the hearings surrounding the case.
- Apple maintains it has never built a backdoor to its products or services and never will.

items.title: Krea raises $83M to be the one-stop shop for genAI creatives
items.author: Victor Perez, Diego Rodriguez
items.summary:
- Krea has raised $83 million to create a unified platform for generative AI aimed at creatives.
- The funding consists of several rounds: $47 million Series B, $33 million Series A, and $3 million preseed/seed.
- Krea is valued at $500 million post-money and supported by Bain Capital Ventures and Andreessen Horowitz.
- The platform simplifies the process of using multiple AI models for designers, enabling easier customization and editing.
- Founders Victor Perez and Diego Rodriguez previously won fellowships from the King of Spain but dropped out of graduate school to pursue Krea.
- Krea aims to enhance creativity rather than automate it, focusing on tools that support creative processes.

items.title: IBM acquires consultancy Hakkoda in continued AI investment push
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- IBM acquired Hakkoda, a data and AI consultancy, for an undisclosed amount.
- The acquisition aims to enhance IBM's consulting capabilities in industries like financial services, public sector, and healthcare.
- Hakkoda, co-founded in 2021, specializes in cloud data migration, particularly to the Snowflake data cloud.
- Hakkoda's consultants will join IBM Consulting as part of the deal.
- IBM has ramped up AI investments, recently acquiring DataStax and HashiCorp, and recorded significant revenue growth in Q4 2024.

items.title: SignalFire raises over $1B as LPs embrace data-driven investing
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- SignalFire secures over $1 billion in fresh capital, totaling around $3 billion in assets under management.
- The firm's unique data-driven investment strategy integrates AI throughout the process, distinguishing it from other VCs.
- Major LPs, including CalPERS, are backing SignalFire due to its focus on seed and pre-seed startups, providing large checks to a scalable firm.
- Future investments will target sector-specific AI startups across various industries, avoiding foundational AI model companies.

items.title: OpenAI reportedly mulls buying Jony Ive and Sam Altman’s AI hardware startup
items.summary:
- OpenAI is reportedly considering acquiring the AI hardware startup io Products, co-founded by Jony Ive and Sam Altman.
- The acquisition price could be around $500 million, according to a report from The Information.
- io Products has raised funding from Laurene Powell Jobs’s Emerson Collective and is working on AI-enabled devices, aiming to be less socially disruptive than the iPhone.

items.title: Someone hacked ransomware gang Everest’s leak site
items.explanation: 'Незнаю' literally means 'I don't know'. You can't beat a giant rock if you can't even make a move!

items.title: Want to stay young? Peter Diamandis says survive the next 10 years
items.summary:
- Peter Diamandis, futurist and founder of XPRIZE Foundation, promotes a vision of an ‘abundant future’ that extends human life through technology.
- Advocates argue technology has improved global living standards, while critics highlight growing inequality.
- Diamandis believes we are nearing 'longevity escape velocity', where advancements in science will extend life significantly within the next decade.
- He emphasizes the importance of diet, sleep, exercise, and a positive mindset for longevity, claiming they are mostly free.
- Further longevity-enhancing methods involve medications, supplements, and advanced testing, with epigenetic reprogramming emerging as a key area of research.
- He launched a Healthspan XPRIZE with $111 million in prize money, aiming to reverse aging in participants aged 60 to 80.
- With 620 teams competing, the prize will be awarded by 2030, showcasing various methods for enhancing longevity.

items.title: Meta’s benchmarks for its new AI models are a bit misleading
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Meta's new AI model, Maverick, ranks second on LM Arena but the version tested differs from the one available to developers.
- LM Arena's testing involved an experimental version of Maverick, leading to possible discrepancies in model performance predictions.
- Researchers have noted variations in output quality between the public version of Maverick and that used in LM Arena, particularly in the use of emojis and response length.

items.title: BBC seeks more prominent credit in Apple and Google News
items.summary:
- The BBC has filed a complaint with the UK’s Competition and Markets Authority regarding Apple News and Google News minimizing credit for featured stories.
- The complaint requests that aggregators be required to more prominently credit news sources, impacting visibility and valuation of the BBC’s content.
- BBC’s funding largely relies on a licence fee from British households, making visibility in news aggregators crucial for maintaining support.
- This follows Apple’s recent pause on AI news summaries due to complaints of inaccuracies from the BBC and other publishers.

items.title: White House reportedly blames auto-suggested iPhone contact for Signal scandal
items.summary:
- The incident involves National Security Adviser Mike Waltz accidentally adding Atlantic editor Jeffrey Goldberg to a Signal group chat with Trump officials discussing Yemen airstrike plans.
- Waltz's iPhone auto-suggested Goldberg's contact after Goldberg emailed the White House, leading to confusion during chat setup.
- An internal investigation revealed this auto-suggestion mechanism caused the mix-up that included Goldberg in the chat.

items.title: Microsoft releases AI-generated Quake II demo, but admits ‘limitations’
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- Microsoft released a browser-based playable demo of Quake II as a tech demo for its Copilot AI platform.
- The demo allows players to interact in a Quake II level using keyboard controls.
- Microsoft researchers highlighted the model's capabilities but acknowledged significant limitations, including fuzzy enemies and issues with object permanence.
- Game designer Austin Walker criticized the demo, emphasizing the importance of understanding game mechanics for effective gameplay.

items.title: DOGE reportedly planning a hackathon to build ‘mega API’ for IRS data
items.author: Gavin Kliger, Sam Corcos
items.summary:
- DOGE to host a hackathon focused on creating a 'mega API' for IRS data access.
- Organized by DOGE staffers at the IRS, Gavin Kliger and Sam Corcos.
- The API aims to provide access to taxpayer data such as names, addresses, and tax returns.
- A third-party vendor, potentially Palantir, will manage parts of the project.
- Concerns raised about sensitive information access without usual security rules.

items.title: Meta releases Llama 4, a new crop of flagship AI models
Deel’s comms chief departs amidst spying lawsuit from Rippling
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Elisabeth Diana, head of communications at Deel, has resigned amid a lawsuit from Rippling accusing Deel of corporate espionage.
- The lawsuit includes serious allegations, such as violation of the RICO act and misappropriation of trade secrets.
- Rippling revealed the name of the accused spy, Keith O’Brien, who appears to confirm the company’s allegations in an affidavit.
- Deel, valued at $12.6 billion, denies any wrongdoing and claims Rippling is deflecting from its own legal issues related to Russian sanctions.
- The future of Deel is uncertain as it was exploring public market entry just two months prior to these events.

items.title: ‘A Minecraft Movie’ is on-track for a $135M opening weekend
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- ‘A Minecraft Movie’ earned $58 million on Friday, forecasted to reach $135 million over the opening weekend.
- This opening would surpass ‘Captain America: Brave New World,’ which made $88.8 million, benefitting the struggling box office.
- The movie adapts the popular video game, directed by Jared Hess, featuring a mix of live-action and Minecraft-style animation.

items.title: Week in Review: Nintendo unveils the Switch 2
items.author: Karyne Levy
items.summary:
- Nintendo announced the release of its Switch successor, the [Switch 2](https://techcrunch.com/2025/04/02/the-nintendo-switch-2-releases-on-june-5-and-costs-450/), set to launch on June 5 for $450.
- The new console aims to enhance the already popular original Switch.
- Preorders in the U.S. may face delays due to [tariffs imposed by former President Trump](https://techcrunch.com/2025/04/04/nintendo-delays-switch-2-preorders-in-response-to-tariffs/).

items.title: SF Mayor Lurie to tech CEOs: ‘How can we get you back?’
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- San Francisco Mayor Daniel Lurie is actively reaching out to tech CEOs to encourage them to stay in or return to the city.
- Addressing the city's drug and homelessness crisis is a priority to retain business leaders.
- Lurie has rolled back a program distributing drug use supplies to combat the crisis.
- A new initiative called Permit SF aims to streamline processes for startups in San Francisco.
- Lurie introduced a zoning proposal to allow taller buildings for increased housing.
- The mayor is advocating for tax breaks to attract AI companies to San Francisco.
- Databricks agreed to hold its AI conference in the city through 2030, influenced by Lurie.
- A new partnership with business leaders has been announced to facilitate communication with city hall.
- Concerns exist over the tech industry's influence on local communities, highlighted by recent Waymo developments.

items.title: ChatGPT adoption skyrockets in India, but monetization may be trailing
Tesla Takes a Hit Amid Tariff Chaos and Milestone for EV Startup
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Tesla faces significant challenges including a drop in Q1 sales, protests, and a falling stock price.
- Recent tariffs announced by Trump may offer some protection to Tesla's U.S. manufacturing but could negatively affect its energy-storage business.
- EV startup Harbinger begins production, marking a milestone with its first 100 salable units, while Rivian reports its worst quarterly deliveries since 2022.

items.title: How Kalshi helped prediction markets go mainstream
items.author: Tarek Mansour, Maggie Stamets
items.summary:
- Kalshi is the largest prediction market in America, focused on political, sports, and cultural events.
- It faces legal challenges, with some states viewing it as requiring gambling licenses.
- CEO Tarek Mansour discusses Kalshi's role as a potential global source of truth in a TechCrunch interview.

items.title: OpenAI’s models ‘memorized’ copyrighted content, new study suggests
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- A new study supports claims that OpenAI trained some AI models on copyrighted content.
- OpenAI faces lawsuits from various rights-holders who allege unauthorized use of their works.
- Researchers at University of Washington, University of Copenhagen, and Stanford co-authored the study.
- The study introduces a method using 'high-surprisal' words to identify memorized training data.
- GPT-4 showed signs of memorizing parts of popular fiction and New York Times articles.
- Abhilasha Ravichander emphasizes the need for transparency in model training data.

items.title: AI has opened a new era in venture capital according to Forerunner Founder Kirsten Green
items.author: Kirsten Green
items.summary:
- Forerunner has achieved numerous high-profile successes by investing in companies ahead of consumer trends, like Oura and Chime.
- TechCrunch Editor in Chief Connie Loizos interviewed founder Kirsten Green about Forerunner's approach in the AI era at a StrictlyVC event in San Francisco.
- The discussion highlighted the firm's strategy and the evolving landscape of venture capital influenced by AI.

items.title: DeepSeek: Everything you need to know about the AI chatbot app
items.summary:
- DeepSeek's chatbot app achieved top rankings in both Apple App Store and Google Play Store.
- The company is backed by High-Flyer Capital Management, focused on AI-driven trading since 2019.
- DeepSeek's models, including DeepSeek-V2 and V3, are recognized for their performance and cost-efficiency, impacting pricing strategies of competitors like ByteDance and Alibaba.
- In March 2025, DeepSeek reached 16.5 million visits, positioning itself as a strong competitor to ChatGPT.
- The AI models, especially the reasoning model R1, undergo regulation to ensure they adhere to Chinese standards.
- Following its rise, DeepSeek has faced bans from entities like the U.S. government on their devices due to security concerns, with many businesses also restricting its use.

items.title: Meta officially says goodbye to its US fact checkers on Monday
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Meta will eliminate all fact-checkers in the U.S. starting Monday.
- This change was announced in January, coinciding with relaxed content moderation rules.
- The decision aligns with President Trump’s inauguration, which Zuckerberg attended after significant donations to Trump's campaign.
- Zuckerberg emphasizes prioritizing speech, potentially harming marginalized communities.
- New fact-checking efforts will resemble Community Notes from Elon Musk’s X, transferring moderation responsibility to users.
- Misinformation has already started to spread due to reduced fact-checking measures, with concerns over topics like immigration and gender identity gaining more visibility.

items.title: Mach CEO on building defense tech company in your 20s
items.author: Ethan Thornton
items.summary:
- Mach CEO Ethan Thornton has been developing weapons systems since high school.
- The company recently secured a contract with the U.S. military.
- Thornton discussed Mach's plans to develop cross-functional factories and compete with China during an interview at the StrictlyVC 2025 event.

items.title: GitHub Copilot introduces new limits, charges for ‘premium’ AI models
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- GitHub announces new 'premium requests' for Copilot, imposing rate limits on advanced AI models.
- Starting May 5, Copilot Pro users will get 300 premium requests; Business and Enterprise users will receive 300 and 1,000, respectively, between May 12 and 19.
- Additional requests cost $0.04 each; a new Pro+ tier at $39 per month offers 1,500 requests and access to top models like GPT-4.5.
- This change reflects higher computing costs associated with complex AI models, despite Copilot generating over 40% of GitHub’s revenue growth in 2024.

items.title: Trump extends TikTok ban deadline by 75 days
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- President Trump has extended the TikTok ban deadline by 75 days, allowing more time to finalize a deal.
- The ban was initially set to take effect on April 5, 2025.
- Trump signed an executive order indicating progress in negotiating with TikTok's parent company, ByteDance.
- A previous deadline for the sale of TikTok's U.S. operations was January 19, set by a law from former President Biden.
- Trump reviewed a proposal from U.S. investors, including Oracle and Blackstone, as a potential deal.
- The Chinese government must approve any finalized deal, which coincides with new tariffs Trump has imposed on China.

items.title: Beyond Bluesky: These are the apps building social experiences on the AT Protocol
items.summary:
- Bluesky, a social network, has surpassed 33 million users and is built on the AT Protocol (ATProto).
- The ATProtocol community recently held the first ATmosphere conference in Seattle, discussing future developments.
- Apps are being created using ATProto to build an open social web, distinct from centralized platforms.
- Notable apps include Flashes, Spark, Pinksky, and Bluescreen, each offering unique features and experiences.
- Streamplace, a livestreaming app, lets users stream videos with high security using the AT Protocol.
- Graze and Surf are innovative tools for managing and customizing feeds on Bluesky.

items.title: Protester interrupts Microsoft Copilot keynote, says company has ‘blood on its hands’
San Francisco Mayor Daniel Lurie thinks his city is on the verge of a rebound
items.summary:
- San Francisco's reputation has declined over the years, impacting its startup culture.
- Mayor Daniel Lurie discusses efforts to revitalize the city and maintain its status in the startup community, particularly in AI development.
- Interview conducted by TechCrunch’s Maxwell Zeff highlights Lurie's administrative and grassroots initiatives.

items.title: Startups Weekly: Stay tuned for the Rippling espionage movie
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- Rippling filed a lawsuit against a former employee accused of spying for rival Deel, with the affidavit resembling a movie script.
- Harbinger accuses Canoo of asset concealment during its bankruptcy sale, alleging favoritism towards Canoo's CEO.
- Qualcomm acquired the generative AI division of VinAI, a Vietnam-based startup.
- Epic Games purchased Loci, an AI tagging platform, for an undisclosed amount.
- Perplexity CEO announced no plans for an IPO before 2028 on Reddit.
- Isomorphic Labs raised $600M, Plaid raised $575M at a $6.1 billion valuation, and several other startups secured significant funding this week.
- Intel Capital is preparing to spin out after operating as Intel's venture investment arm since 1991.

items.title: Flexport CEO Ryan Petersen still sees opportunity in global trade despite Trump’s tariffs
items.summary:
- Flexport CEO Ryan Petersen discusses the impact of new U.S. tariffs on international trade during a conversation with TechCrunch Editor in Chief Connie Loizos.
- The tariffs have plunged international trade into chaos, affecting the supply chain business that Flexport is built on.
- Despite the challenges, Petersen maintains a long-term optimistic outlook on global trade opportunities.

items.title: Gemini 2.5 Pro is Google’s most expensive AI model yet
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Google released pricing for its Gemini 2.5 Pro AI reasoning model on April 4, 2025.
- Pricing is $1.25 per million input tokens and $10 per million output tokens for prompts up to 200,000 tokens.
- For prompts over 200,000 tokens, pricing increases to $2.50 for input and $15 for output tokens.
- Gemini 2.5 Pro is more expensive than previous models like Gemini 2.0 Flash and competitors such as OpenAI’s o3-mini and DeepSeek’s R1.
- Competitively, it remains cheaper than models like Anthropic’s Claude 3.7 Sonnet and OpenAI’s GPT-4.5.
- Usage is high; Google reports an 80% increase in Gemini API usage this month.
- Growing demand and rising computing costs may drive the trend of higher pricing in flagship AI models.

items.title: Klarna and StubHub delay IPOs because of Trump tariff turmoil
items.summary:
- Klarna and StubHub are postponing their IPOs due to market volatility following President Trump's tariff announcements.
- Both companies had recently filed for IPOs, aiming to raise at least $1 billion each.
- They were scheduled to start their road shows to investors next week but have chosen to delay the process.

items.title: Microsoft’s Copilot can now browse the web and perform actions for you
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Microsoft’s Copilot can now perform actions on most websites, including booking tickets and making restaurant reservations.
- The AI can remember user preferences and analyze real-time video.
- Copilot has partnered with numerous companies (1-800-Flowers.com, Booking.com, etc.) for initial features.
- Users can prompt Copilot to track deals and notify them of sales.
- A new podcast-generation feature allows Copilot to create dialogues from sources.
- The app can access phone camera views and desktop information to assist with tasks.
- There are new features for organizing notes and conducting deep research based on multiple sources.
- Users have control over what information Copilot remembers, with options to delete memories.

items.title: Turbine raises $22M to help VC investors get cash without selling their stakes
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Turbine raised $22 million in equity funding, co-led by Alpha Edison and TTV Capital.
- The startup provides a credit product for limited partners in venture capital, allowing them to borrow funds secured by their LP positions.
- Turbine has secured up to $100 million in debt from Silicon Valley Bank to support its lending operations.
- The interest rate on loans from Turbine is around 9%, deemed reasonable compared to potential losses from selling stakes on secondary markets.

items.title: A comprehensive list of 2025 tech layoffs
items.summary:
- The tech layoff wave continues in 2025 with over 22,000 jobs lost so far.
- February 2025 alone saw 16,084 layoffs across various companies in the tech industry.
- Companies like Automattic, Canva, Northvolt, and Block have announced significant layoffs, impacting thousands of employees.
- The layoffs are part of broader trends towards AI and automation, raising concerns about the human impact of these changes.
- A regular update will be provided on all known layoffs in the tech sector for 2025.
